repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Eleanor "Elly" Elliott was a women's rights activist, a board member of NOW's Legal Defense and Education Fund, a Barnard College Board Member, served on the National Advisory Council on Women's Educational Programs and was an editor at Vogue magazine. These materials consist of personal papers from the Elliott family and administrative files from Elliott's work in various women's rights organizations and philanthropic activities. It also includes photographs, scrapbooks and some audio/visual materials.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research with the exception of the Barnard College series, which is restricted until 2025.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Eleanor Elliott Papers, Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Eleanor Elliott Papers were received by the Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library as a gift in 2007-2018.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Alexandra Krensky and Megan Lewis, February 2011
Encoded by Alexandra Krensky and Megan Lewis, February 2011

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Eleanor Lansing Thomas "Elly" Elliott was a women's rights advocate who is best-known for successfully fighting Columbia University's attempt to take over Barnard College in the early 1970s. She served on the Barnard Board of Trustees for over 40 years beginning in 1959. She was President of the Board from 1973 to 1976. In the early 1950's, she served as the social secretary to the U.S. Secretary of State and her cousin, John Foster Dulles. In the 1970s she began serving on the board of directors of the Celanese Corporation. She was also a board member of the National Organization for Women's Legal Defense and Education Fund. In the 1980s, she served on the National Advisory Council on Women's Educational Programs. In the early 1990s, she was chairwoman of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation. She was a Life Trustee of New York-Presbyterian Hospital and a Life Overseer of Weill Cornell Medical College. She received an honorary doctorate of letters from Duke University in 2002 for her "advocacy for women in health and education." Her husband of 48 years, Jock Elliott, was a former chairman of the advertising firm Ogilvy and Mather.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: These papers consist of personal materials from the Elliott and Thomas families as well as administrative files from Elliott's work in various women's rights organizations and philanthropic activities.

The collection includes some material regarding Elly's husband, Jock Elliott, former chairman of the Ogilvy and Mather advertising firm. Included in the Thomas family materials is a series on Eleanor's mother, Dorothy Q. Thomas. In the legal and financial papers series, there are materials pertaining to the divorce and child support matters of Elliott's brother, James A. Thomas Jr.
The collection contains scrapbooks and photographs, as well as reel-to-reel audiotapes that require reformatting before use.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Materials related to Elliott's husband, Jock, can be found in the Jock Elliott Papers. Materials related to Elliott's father, James A. Thomas, can be found in the James Augustus Thomas Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These materials document Eleanor Elliott's family of origin. Much of the material pertains to her mother, Dorothy Q. Thomas.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Files are arranged by subject, and by alphabetical, then chronological arrangement within those subjects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material documenting Eleanor Elliott's work with various organizations as well as her philanthropic activity.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into three subseries: Correspondence, Research Files, and Writings and Speeches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Eleanor Elliott's writings consist of published pieces in Glamour, Vogue, Town and Country and by the Feminist Press. They also include files from an unpublished memoir. Speeches were given at the following institutions and events, among others: The National Conference of Christians and Jews, The National Association of Fund Raising Executives, Colony Club, New York Association for the Blind, Columbia Graduate School of Business, International House of New York, Women's Forum Meeting, Forum for Women Directors, New York Junior League, Planned Giving Group of New York, Center for the Study of Philanthropy, Women and Money Conference, New York Hospital, St. Nicholas Society, United Hospital Fund, Women's Health Symposium, Meeting of Women and Foundations-Corporate Philanthropy; Celanese Forum for Women Directors.

did.unittitle: Vogue, June 1973 and Town and Country, 1975

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bound scrapbooks are arranged in original order, with original numbering noted in Roman Numerals by their creators. Scrapbooks missing from the Roman Numeral sequence were not received as part of this collection. Loose materials intended to be mounted in the scrapbooks is included in Box 37. Materials include clippings, photographs, correspondence, programs and miscellaneous printed items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Legal and Financial papers of the Elliott and Thomas families including estate papers, wills, appraisals of property, and legal correspondence regarding the estates of the two families.

Also included are the legal and financial documents and correspondence pertaining to the divorce, custody, and child support matters of Elliott's brother, James A. Thomas Jr. and his wife Anne Macdonald Thomas.

did.unittitle: James A. Thomas, Jr. divorce and child support proceedings
Memorabilia and ephemera from various family events, travel itineraries and journals, and articles about Eleanor Elliott and Jock Elliott, among other items
New York Hospital Life Governor Award, 1996
Jock Elliott memorabilia from Apollo 11 launch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is divided into four subseries: Personal, Jock and Eleanor Elliott, Family, and Funeral and Sympathy. Within these subseries, correspondence is arranged in rough chronological order, unless otherwise specified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Noted correspondents include Richard Rogers, David Ogilvy and Louis Auchincloss.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence to Eleanor Elliott's family after her death, as well as correspondence written to Eleanor Elliott after the passing of her husband, Jock and her brother, James A. Thomas, Jr.
